results.title: Sequins and sapphires
results.brief_description: Two of the most striking costumes on the big and small screens embody the glamour of leading First Peoples ladies.

constellations_primary.name: Sequins and sapphires
constellations_primary.description: Two of the most striking costumes on the big and small screens embody the glamour of leading First Peoples ladies.

results.description:
This form-fitting blue sequin dress worn by Julie (Jessica Mauboy) in The Sapphires (2012) is front and centre in the true story of an Indigenous singing group who entertained troops during the Vietnam War. It reflects late-1960s fashion and featured in the film’s posters and during critical scenes, including the fan-favourite performance of ‘Sugar Pie, Honey Bunch’ at the film’s end.

Equally as fabulous is the bright pink tinsel dress worn by Kitty (Elaine Crombie) in Kiki and Kitty (2017). As Kiki’s (Nakkiah Lui) fairy god-vagina, Kitty shimmers in this sensual, sequined ensemble and embodies all the repressed sass and sauciness of Lui’s buttoned-down lawyer.

“A vagina that came to life… was like someone who would essentially be my friend and who would stick up for me and they would wear sequins and drink martinis and just be all the things I kind of wish I was.” - Nakkiah Lui
description_for_label:
This form-fitting blue sequin dress worn by Julie (Jessica Mauboy) in The Sapphires (2012) is front and centre in the true story of an Indigenous singing group who entertained troops during the Vietnam War. It reflects late-1960s fashion and featured in the film’s posters and during critical scenes, including the fan-favourite performance of ‘Sugar Pie, Honey Bunch’ at the film’s end.

Equally as fabulous is the bright pink tinsel dress worn by Kitty (Elaine Crombie) in Kiki and Kitty (2017). As Kiki’s (Nakkiah Lui) fairy god-vagina, Kitty shimmers in this sensual, sequined ensemble and embodies all the repressed sass and sauciness of Lui’s buttoned-down lawyer.

“A vagina that came to life… was like someone who would essentially be my friend and who would stick up for me and they would wear sequins and drink martinis and just be all the things I kind of wish I was.” - Nakkiah Lui

results.title:
Sequential photographs
Motion Studies: Straight High Jump
results.credit_line: Courtesy Heritage Image Partnership Ltd / World History Archive / Welcome Collection / Alamy
results.brief_description: British American photographer Eadweard Muybridge laid the foundation of the moving image. Using multiple cameras triggered by trip wires, he captured a galloping horse in sequential images, reproduced them in a zoetrope and created the world’s first moving photographs.
results.credit_line_for_label: Courtesy Heritage Image Partnership Ltd / World History Archive / Welcome Collection / Alamy

results.title: Sequences of behavior (TEFC)
results.brief_description:
Episode number 4 of Series “Behavior Theory in Practice”.
Shows procedure for conditioning homogeneous and heterogeneous behaviour chains. Demonstrates shaping of complex behaviour chains in pigeons, dogs in obedience trials, police dogs and guide dogs, showing practical application of laboratory findings

results.title: Sequence and story
results.creator_credit: Don White, George Johnson and ONF | NFB
results.brief_description:
In this film a group of children manipulate reality using a series of photographs of their own activities. As they lay out the photos in different sequences, the story of their day changes. Simple, realistic dialogue and a combination of live action and still photographs capture the viewer’s imagination.
Suitable for middle and upper primary levels.

results.title: Sequel to Surtsey
results.brief_description: Shows the volcanic activity of the island of Surtsey near Iceland throughout 1965-l966. Submarine eruptions create the temporary neighbouring islands of Syrtlingur and Jolnir, reduced to shoals soon after they cease erupting. After a quiescent period new eruptions begin on Surtsey itself. Meanwhile scientific investigations continue, a permanent base is established and plant life appears. A continuation of the film Birth of an Island (502828).
